title: How to Keep Silverfish Away from Books Naturally

steps.headline: Make sure that the sprigs are dry.
steps.description: They can be fresh but must not be damp.

steps.headline: Place the thyme sprigs behind the books on each shelf.
steps.description: Bruise a little to release the scent. Silverfish do not like thyme and will keep away.

steps.headline: Replace every few months.
steps.description: Grow some thyme indoors to help with this exercise.

steps.headline: Set traps near or on bookshelves.
Clean medium to tall height jars.
steps.description: Remove the labels and allow to dry.

steps.headline: Wrap the jar with masking tape, fabric or another surface material insects can climb up.
steps.description: Do this all of the way to the top.

steps.headline: Place food attractants inside the jar.
steps.description: This can be cereal, oats, oatmeal, crumbled crackers or dry cookie crumbs.

steps.headline: Place near the books.
steps.description: Check regularly; the silverfish crawl in to get the food but cannot climb back up the glass surface to get out. Empty the jar and put back in place.

steps.headline: Mix 1 teaspoon lavender oil to approximately 300ml/ 1/2 pint of water.
Spray on surfaces affected by silverfish.
steps.description: Vacuum first, then spray. Remove all of the books from the shelves and wipe them down completely. Allow to dry before returning the books.

steps.headline: Spray other areas too.
steps.description: The more areas covered, the less areas the silverfish will be happy to launch their attack from.

steps.headline: Mix 1 teaspoon of honey with 1 teaspoon of baking soda.
Cut small squares of card.
steps.description: A cereal box is ideal, especially if it smells like cereal!

steps.headline: Smear small amounts of the honey and baking soda mix.
Place the little squares on the bookshelves.
steps.description: Place some at the back of the books, and some at the front. If the silverfish nibble on these squares, it will be toxic to them.

steps.headline: Remove and replace the squares regularly.

text: Thyme Cut some sprigs of thyme.  Make sure that the sprigs are dry. They can be fresh but must not be damp. Place the thyme sprigs behind the books on each shelf. Bruise a little to release the scent. Silverfish do not like thyme and will keep away. Replace every few months. Grow some thyme indoors to help with this exercise. Traps Set traps near or on bookshelves.  Clean medium to tall height jars. Remove the labels and allow to dry. Wrap the jar with masking tape, fabric or another surface material insects can climb up. Do this all of the way to the top. Place food attractants inside the jar. This can be cereal, oats, oatmeal, crumbled crackers or dry cookie crumbs. Place near the books. Check regularly; the silverfish crawl in to get the food but cannot climb back up the glass surface to get out. Empty the jar and put back in place. Lavender oil Mix 1 teaspoon lavender oil to approximately 300ml/ 1/2 pint of water. Shake to combine well. Spray on surfaces affected by silverfish. Vacuum first, then spray. Remove all of the books from the shelves and wipe them down completely. Allow to dry before returning the books. Spray other areas too. The more areas covered, the less areas the silverfish will be happy to launch their attack from. Baking soda and honey Mix 1 teaspoon of honey with 1 teaspoon of baking soda. Mix to form a paste. Cut small squares of card. A cereal box is ideal, especially if it smells like cereal! Smear small amounts of the honey and baking soda mix. Allow to dry. Place the little squares on the bookshelves. Place some at the back of the books, and some at the front. If the silverfish nibble on these squares, it will be toxic to them. Remove and replace the squares regularly.
